item.title: Top Sinaloa cartel leader taken into U.S. custody alongside son of ‘El Chapo’
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Sheridan, Nick Miroff
item.description: Ismael “El Mayo” Zambada and Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman were co-directors of the massive Sinaloa drug-trafficking organization before the latter’s arrest.

item.title: Harris calls for cease-fire and hostage release after Netanyahu meeting
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, John Hudson
item.description: The White House is trying to pressure the Israeli prime minister to accept terms of a cease-fire and hostage-release deal.

item.title: How Paris made the city the stage for the 2024 Olympics
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack
item.description: Instead of building new stadiums, Paris is embedding Olympic events in the French capital and hoping to highlight its history and green transformation.

item.title: New U.K. state company to develop offshore wind on seabed owned by Charles III
item.dc:creator: Karla Adam
item.description: The Crown Estate, the monarchy’s real estate firm, owns much of the seabed surrounding Britain.

item.title: Divers discover 19th-century shipwreck laden with 100 champagne bottles
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: Any plan to pop the corks will have to wait until further exploration, the team said.

item.title: Israel recovers bodies of five hostages amid delay in latest talks on deal
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid, Susannah George
item.description: Israeli media contrasted the news about the recovery of the bodies with Benjamin Netanyahu’s triumphant speech in the United States and the lack of a hostage deal.

item.title: NORAD intercepts Russian, Chinese bombers off Alaskan coast
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset
item.description: Defense officials have noted increased China-Russia cooperation in the Arctic, while cautioning that their collaboration is still “somewhat superficial.”

item.title: Russia is banned from the Paris Olympics. Here’s what that means.
item.dc:creator: Matt Bonesteel
item.description: Russia is banned from the Paris Olympics, but its athletes aren’t. Instead, they’ll be competing as Individual Neutral Athletes, without their country’s flags.

item.title: Wildfire reaches resort town of Jasper as Alberta battles over 170 blazes
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Ables
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said “every necessary resource available” was being mobilized as wildfires rage across the western Canadian province.

item.title: The ordinary people risking everything to protect Venezuela’s vote
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt, Ana Herrero
item.description: In a country where the authoritarian president is accused of rigging elections — disqualifying challengers, barring international observers, harassing opponents, menacing voters — their work could prove essential.

item.title: Sanctions crushed Syria’s elite. So they built a zombie economy fueled by drugs.
item.dc:creator: Joby Warrick, Souad Mekhennet
item.description: A U.S.-led sanctions campaign aimed to force Syria’s brutal leaders to step aside. A multibillion-dollar illicit drug industry arose to preserve their grip on power.

item.title: Komodo dragons have iron-coated teeth to rip apart prey, scientists find
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jeong
item.description: The study’s lead author said it provided insight into how the lizards keep their teeth razor sharp — and possible clues to how dinosaurs like Tyrannosaurus rex hunted.

item.title: As Netanyahu hails Gaza war effort, hobbled Hamas government clings to power
item.dc:creator: Miriam Berger, Hajar Harb
item.description: As law and order collapse in Gaza, Hamas has retained pockets of power and has been quick to reemerge in areas where Israeli forces have withdrawn.

item.title: Twice-a-year shot provides 100 percent HIV protection, study finds
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: None of the 5,000 women and girls in South Africa and Uganda who received the shots contracted the virus that causes AIDS, a study shows. A trial for men is underway.

item.title: Netanyahu dismisses critics, scolds protesters in defiant speech to Congress
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner, Steve Hendrix, Louisa Loveluck
item.description: Evoking Israel’s sworn enemy Iran, Benjamin Netanyahu told Congress his nation’s campaign against Hamas in Gaza is part of a broader fight against “barbarism.”

item.title: Anti-Israel protests and threats set tone for politically charged Olympics
item.dc:creator: Rick Noack, Claire Parker
item.description: The Israeli soccer team took the field in Paris on Wednesday in one of the first events of an extremely tense Summer Olympics.

item.title: U.K. royals to get big raise as Crown Estate sees record $1.4 billion profit
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: The Crown Estate’s profits more than doubled in the past year, partly due to lucrative offshore wind farm leases on land owned by the monarchy, meaning a windfall for them and the government.

item.title: North Korean balloon drops trash on South Korean presidential office
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch
item.description: The airborne garbage delivery was the latest, and perhaps most humiliating, episode in the ongoing trash-offensive.

item.title: Netanyahu’s history of clashing with U.S. presidents spans decades
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall, Joe Snell
item.description: As Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu meets with President Biden in Washington on Thursday, here is a look back at some of his most notable clashes with U.S. presidents.

item.title: 1972 Munich Olympics, marred by killing of Israeli athletes, loom over Paris Games
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth
item.description: The 2024 Paris Olympics begin this weekend amid the global fallout over the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel by Hamas and the Gaza war.

item.title: American reality show contestant kills, eats protected bird in New Zealand
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset
item.description: Spencer “Corry” Jones apologized after killing a weka, a large flightless bird with “a famously feisty and curious personality,” on “Race to Survive: New Zealand.”

item.title: Plane slips off runway and crashes at Kathmandu airport, killing 18
item.dc:creator: Sangam Prasai, Maham Javaid
item.description: The Saurya Airlines plane was taking off from Nepal’s Tribhuvan International Airport runway when it flipped, eyewitnesses said. A child is among the dead.

item.title: How ‘carbon cowboys’ are cashing in on protected Amazon forest
item.dc:creator: Terrence McCoy, Júlia Ledur, Marina Dias
item.description: A six-month investigation reveals that many carbon credit ventures reap profits from public lands they have no right to and fail to share revenue with those protecting the forest.

item.title: Taiwan braces for Typhoon Gaemi, set to be the most severe in eight years
item.dc:creator: Vic Chiang, Christian Shepherd
item.description: The powerful storm has already caused deaths and devastation in the Philippines and is now bearing down on Taiwan, where emergency measures are in place.

item.title: Maduro’s decade of authoritarian rule: A visual timeline
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt, Ana Herrero, Jennifer Samuel
item.description: How Venezuela’s socialist strongman took and consolidated power — and why the opposition now sees cause for hope.

item.title: Sharks test positive for cocaine in Brazil’s drug-polluted waters
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: Brazilian sharpnose sharks found with cocaine in their livers and muscles highlight the impact of the illegal drug trade on marine life, scientists say.

item.title: As Netanyahu addresses Congress, agony in Gaza endures
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The first time Netanyahu addressed Congress was nearly three decades ago. Now, he arrives in the U.S. amid devastation in Gaza and discontent in Israel.
